they have struggled for a state since

forward with an independence vote which
could redraw the map of the Middle East
Shao Kahn Amin didn't live to see it
he was a fighter with the Kurdish pesh
MERGA killed last year in the big push
against Isis here his family told me
they have paid in blood for their
freedom and the international opposition
won't stop them but karate me for the
past hundred years they have been
telling us it's not the right time if we
don't move forward they will be telling
us that for the next hundred years the
nation is united there won't be a better
time than now at what we say hakuna whoa
but there are possible flash points like
the oil-rich city of Kirkuk as the vote
approaches you can sense the tension
the city is multi-ethnic it's controlled
by the Kurds but also claimed by the
government in Baghdad Arab leaders in
Kirkuk say their community won't accept
the referendum results and is
increasingly fearful a lot of people are
taking their valuables away for
safekeeping
whether it's expensive cars or large
sums of cash everyone want to protect
themselves people have started to
stockpile food they are very afraid of
what is coming either
another massacre but at the Peshmerga
frontline they are poised for victory
after their long battle for freedom
veterans here fought the Iraqis in the
past but lately the so-called Islamic
state
commander Kemal kir cookie says they are
still in position about a mile away
he says the Kurds will remain focused on
the enemy we make a decision and to
continue fighting against Isis until
they will be finishing there because
they are not only danger for us they are
all the earth they are danger for
democracy so the referendum will not
interfere with the fight against me but
the cards may soon be moving into
unknown territory Iraq's neighbors who
have their own Kurdish minorities are
looking on anxiously there is
uncertainty here and in the
international community about what will
follow the referendum Kurdish commanders
tell us they want to move peacefully to
independence they don't want trouble
with Baghdad or with the neighboring
states but they say if conflict should
come they are ready to fight
at the final rallies the promises of
better days to come after what the Kurds
are calling their brexit but if the
referendum goes ahead as planned a new
stage could be born into conflict or
